displayed_text: Patient: This was more down in the sacroiliac. Doctor: Yes, uh hum. Patient: Uh and there’s a – he injected the left and right both. Doctor: That’s where he injected it. Both sides, okay. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Both sides, and - Doctor: All right. Patient: Yeah. Healthcare Professional: Still having constipation issues? Come and go? Patient: Of course (chuckles) Doctor: Okay, so with the chemo now, the things to keep track of any kind of fevers, infections, anything I need to know right away. Family Member: Yes.

Patient: Mm,hmm. Doctor: - like a bread loaf. (Makes slicing sound) Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: from before and there were three spots that only had a little bit of cancer. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: We talked about that on the phone, that’s I don’t know how to explain that. Family Member: I don’t know how you miss all that. Doctor: It would look like the needle would hit more. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: Do you want this. There’s the picture over here. Those are the slices. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: There’s lymph nodes all along there. So at different places uh- Patient: Are there new ones or it’s the same ones that are just enlarged? I mean- Doctor: It looks like the same ones have enlarged a bit. Patient: So what, so what does that tell us? Doctor: Well, it’s confusing because some are actually smaller. Uh up in the chest. So one for instance was point nine centimeters. Now it’s point six. And one was uh, uh. That’s actually a little bigger. Uh but the ones in the abdomen and lower down have all gotten bigger. So for the most part by a few millimeters. Patient: Hum. Doctor: So but enough change that, that I think we’re probably not going in the- Patient: In the right direction. Doctor: In the right direction. So I think you know we didn’t get much response to the enzalutamide or that. It sounds, it seems like your cancer may just not be hormonally sensitive at this point. Patient: Okay. Doctor: To kind of go both ways, a low hormone, high hormone.

Family Member: Yeah guess the question I have is, what if for some reason the roads are really bad, the weather’s really bad? Are you flexible? Doctor: Oh, we would just reschedule. Oh, yes. We would never put you at risk for safety. If let's say you're just sick with something, it's not cancer related. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You don't come down. You got to do this hard thing. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Sometimes we have to be a little bit off cycle because, again, the weather for us is usually the big thing. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: But sometimes it's vacation and special events and life. Patient: . Right now. Family Member: Okay, what if he goes on chemo- Doctor: Uh huh. Family Member: How is his reaction or side effects kind of differ from the way they are right now.

Healthcare Professional: So Doctor: Oh yeah so now did you actually throw up after the chemo last time? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: How often? How many days? Patient: Two, three days after I had one at home Doctor: Mhmm. Patient: then I had the heat flashes Doctor: Mhmm. Patient: and I still have them every now and then. Doctor: Mhmm. Oh okay so that’s… Patient: And then (pause) Doctor: Okay. No because I was looking into let me just see if we have to increase his uh… Are you driving back home on your own? Patient: No. My mom she’s…

Patient: Yeah, yeah. (chuckles) Doctor: This is such a generous gift. Today today I am wearing my uh socks. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: You know Patient: Oh they talking about sending some in December, you heard. Just some socks. Doctor: I did. Patient: Yeah, mhm. Doctor: But next time you come in I going to have to wear these. Doctor: The polka dot socks. Patient: Yeah. (laughs) Doctor: Perfect. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: It goes there for now. How have you been?

Patient: Uh (relation) Doctor: So it’s not direct. It would be well I’m super tired or my stomach doesn’t feel good then I eat and drink less. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then you’re dehydrated and your - and organ like kidney or liver takes a hit. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Gotcha. Doctor: That’s the problem. Patient: I’m not eating less. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I do feel that I’m eating better… Um… Family Member: Mhmm. Doctor: Yeah because you got a week off.

Family Member: The trial, yeah. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. I’ll, I’ll clarify that today. Okay? As soon as we’re done. Uh, there’s two different groups I’ve got to talk to, uh, about that. Uh, then I will, uh, I’ll get that information to you as soon as I have it. And if I don’t- Family Member: But one, one of them you said that he’d get both drugs. So he’d probably want to do that one, I guess. Because one you get one and the other one you’re going to get both. You just get the- Patient: You talking about the one with the prednisone? Family Member: No. Doctor: No. No. That’s the Zytiga drug. We’re going to table that for now. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. One is a random study, study, so it’s like a, there’s a possibility you just get the standard, the drug. The other I think- Family Member: You get both? Doctor: You get both. Okay? Family Member: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: The good thing about that in addition to the survival is you have pain relief with that. So, actually if you didn’t have any pain, I couldn’t get that cleared through insurance because they only want people who have discomfort and pain. I’m not saying you have to be writhing on the floor Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: but you have to sort of say oh, yeah, I get pain so, you know, I know I have cancer. Um, but you’re actually a good candidate for that. You’re otherwise all your blood counts and everything is also good because if you were already coming in here with low white cells or low red cells you wouldn’t be great but you don’t have that problem. So, Patient: Okay. Doctor: maybe the next step should be this medicine called Xofigo which, you know, we can have a side effects sheet given to you. We have to run it through insurance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That might take a minute. Patient: Okay. Family Member: In addition to the radium or that? Doctor: No, that is the radium. Patient: Oh, that is the radium. Doctor: Yeah. So, there’s different names.

Patient: Potassium was a little off. Doctor: Okay. We’ll, we’ll check you out for that. You know? You’re here because when Dr. S___, he did the lung biopsy or at least he told those guys to do a lung biopsy, it shows prostate cancer in your lungs. So not lung cancer. So in some sense a little bit of a relief but you still have your cancer of the – Patient: Of the prostate. Doctor: - prostate in your lungs. Now, you had that in twenty sixteen. It’s just that there’s more of it and slightly bigger. So that’s why I got you. When I went to, I sent you to Dr. S___, it was like well what are we going to do? Well, I need to take a sample. So he thought about going down this way. If you remember to try to get a sample from that, but he thought getting it through the outside would be just fine. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Which way did it get it? From the left side or right side? Doctor: The biopsy? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Ooh, I want to say left. Uh, I think it was the left, and then they did the special stains underneath the microscope, and, you know, looked for actual prostate stains, and it was positive on both of them. So now the question is, you started your hormone shot back up, and you’ve kind of been on it the whole time. It’s just you were delayed a little bit on one day, one of them, and now it’s you need another medicine. But I want to make sure that you are well healed from your pneumonia before we go ahead and do that. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Probably, you know, another several weeks or so until you feel like you’re back on your feet, uh, and over the flu, the pneumonia, and all that, but we think you’re going to need a set of pills to kind of help keep the prostate in check.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and then you randomize it. In other words, you flip a coin. You give half of them a specified dose of Metformin and you give the other half a placebo immunotherapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then at the end of the day you look at the outcomes and you see are the recurrence rates you know slowed down less in the patients that receive the Metformin or alternatively our prevention rates that with time those that don’t receive the Metformin. The - the type of studies that have suggested that Metformin is beneficial, the so-called epidemiological studies. In other words, given the retrospectives, where they take a series of patients – Patient: Got it. Doctor: - and they go back and ask them based on questionnaires Were you taking Metformin and when did you start and how long? What was the reason for being on it? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And they would ask about the dose as well. So at any rate, to answer your question that the advise on the Metformin is if you have another reason to be on it. Patient: Yes. Doctor: For example, if you have a slight gluco-spasm where the glucose is a little bit elevated or if you have you know clinical type two diabetes. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Then it may also be beneficial for your prostate cancer, but the prostate cancer I wouldn’t say should be the primary reason for being on it. Patient: Uh hum.

Patient: Right. Doctor: But because of that threat I’m tempted to say maybe we should get it in control while we can rather than waiting until that bad outcome happens. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that’s why I’ll have Dr. C____ come in first, explain the procedure, what it involves, what the risks are, all of that – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - and then I’ll just touch base with you after he’s spoken to. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that way if any questions… Family Member: You’ll come back today you mean? Doctor: Yeah. I do. Yeah, yeah. Family Member: I didn’t know if we have to come back. Doctor: I figured if he explained to you first and then if any questions come up and all that, I will come back. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: And then it feels so funny man like… Doctor: Okay, I got it. Let me have gastroenterology see you because they may need to scope you both down below as well as in the stomach, okay? First of all because your diarrhea is not something that’s typically happens with this chemotherapy. Okay so we need to get to the bottom of what’s causing you diarrhea also. Alright? Patient: Right. That’s the - that’s the thing that they, man, I can eat, I can eat, but. Doctor: Okay. I got that. Patient: I couldn’t eat nothing. Doctor: But you could not… Patient: I could eat nothing for about, about at least about two days. Doctor: Okay so let me send me over to chemo. Okay? We’ll do the chemo today, but meanwhile I’m going to call our radiologist and see if they can tell me something about the CAT scan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Then I’ll come over there and talk to you about it. Patient: Let me ask you something, let me ask you something Dr. B____. What is what is better, CAT scan or ah MRI? Doctor: It depends on what part of the body we’re looking at. But a CAT scan is pretty good, it’s a pretty good test. If we don’t find something or need to look at it more. Patient: You said it’s not showing on the…

Patient: What time would it be? Doctor: I don’t know. What time do you prefer? Family Member: Not Friday because you’re helping me with my health fair. Doctor: Fair enough. Patient: Uh how about um… Family Member: Thursday you’re seeing P in the morning. Patient: Yeah. Could we do it Thursday afternoon? Doctor: Sure, yeah. Family Member: It’s just an echo… Patient: How long does it take – to do that ? Doctor: It’s about, not a very long time, but it would mean that I would just need to, we would need to coordinate the echo appointment and all that- that’s why I’m just asking you for Patient: Thursday afternoon.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.American Indian or Alaska Native: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::American Indian or Alaska Native

displayed_text: Family Member: And I had to go in. Dr. F___ was over at the C___’s Hospital. I went in with Dr. S____. Doctor: You did not tell me she had a mini-stroke. Family Member: They put a PFO closure and found a hole in my heart. Doctor: Why didn’t you tell me? Oh, gosh. Family Member: Yeah. I have a closure piece in there. Doctor: You okay now? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: She looks great. Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Actually, you both, you both have come a long way. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: From our first days of meeting. Family Member: Oh, yeah, yes, yes. Right?
